docs.lead_paragraph: Updated | Sept. 9, 2010 The next time you're buying a product like a car, a piece of furniture, an electronic device or a trip, here's another reminder to think twice before agreeing to buy some insurance related to that product.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some hospitals, medical device makers and drug companies are experiencing something of a lull, and a new Wall Street research report suggests it's likely get worse before it gets better. In a report issued on Friday, Charles Boorady, an equity analyst at Credit Suisse, predicts the current slowdown will likely continue for the rest of the year.

headline.main: What's Behind the Slowdown in Health Care

docs.abstract: The economy has been part of the reason why people are using health care less than before, according to an analyst.
docs.snippet: The economy has been part of the reason why people are using health care less than before, according to an analyst.

docs.lead_paragraph: Consumers who are shopping for their own health insurance have the option of hiring a broker -- someone who will, free of charge, help you price and compare various plans, as explained in today's Patient Money column.

headline.main: Using a Broker to Buy Health Insurance

docs.abstract: Health insurance brokers can help consumers buying individual policies find and compare different policies, today's Patient Money reports.
docs.snippet: Health insurance brokers can help consumers buying individual policies find and compare different policies, today's Patient Money reports.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline.main: Friday Reading: Evidence of Ticket Quotas

docs.abstract: The mounting evidence in New York of ticket quotas, why the penny should be abolished and other consumer-focused items from Friday's Times.
docs.snippet: The mounting evidence in New York of ticket quotas, why the penny should be abolished and other consumer-focused items from Friday's Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline.main: For Whom Does the Health Insurance Broker Work?

docs.abstract: The health care overhaul is unlikely to endanger brokers, but their role in bringing together providers and the insured will continue to raise potential conflicts, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: The health care overhaul is unlikely to endanger brokers, but their role in bringing together providers and the insured will continue to raise potential conflicts, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: The prerequisite for a jobless person’s qualifying for a federal health insurance plan might compel some to risk going without any coverage for six months.

docs.lead_paragraph: 6:44 p.m. | Updated In his Political Times column on Wednesday, Matt Bai asserted that President Obama had missed an opportunity to rally the public behind his long-term initiative to restructure the economy. He is answering readers' questions about the president's approach and other top political issues this week.

headline.main: Obama's Missed Opportunity: Answers From Matt Bai, Part I

docs.abstract: Matt Bai answers readers' questions about President Obama's approach to the economy.
docs.snippet: Matt Bai answers readers' questions about President Obama's approach to the economy.
